message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations
Paper Abstract: Social conventions are the backbone of social coordination, shaping how individuals form a group. As growing populations of artificial intelligence (AI) agents communicate through natural language, a fundamental question is whether they can bootstrap the foundations of a society. Here, we present experimental results that demonstrate the spontaneous emergence of universally adopted social conventions in decentralized populations of large language model (LLM) agents. We then show how strong collective biases can emerge during this process, even when agents exhibit no bias individually. Last, we examine how committed minority groups of adversarial LLM agents can drive social change by imposing alternative social conventions on the larger population. Our results show that AI systems can autonomously develop social conventions without explicit programming and have implications for designing AI systems that align, and remain aligned, with human values and societal goals.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I found comprehensive information about natural language processing. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

### Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Recent Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models emerged in late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Based on the search results, here's information about large language models:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

## Limitations

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

Links: [{"title":"Convention (norm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(norm)"},{"title":"Social norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_norm"},{"title":"Category:Social conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_conventions"},{"title":"Category:Cultural conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cultural_conventions"},{"title":"Comedy of manners - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_of_manners"},{"title":"Conventionalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conventionalism"},{"title":"List of International Labour Organization Conventions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ILO_Conventions"},{"title":"Cultural code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_code"},{"title":"Convention (meeting) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(meeting)"},{"title":"Social constructionism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_constructionism"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about social conventions:

## Definition

A convention is a selection from among two or more alternatives, where the rule or alternative is agreed upon among participants.(no content)Often the word refers to unwritten customs shared throughout a community.

## Key Characteristics

A social norm or norm is a shared standard of acceptable behavior by a group.(no content)Social norms can both be informal understandings that govern the behavior of members of a society, as well as be codified into rules and laws.(no content)Norms are contingent on context, social group, and historical circumstances.

## How Conventions Function

Economist and game theorist Peyton Young defines norms as "patterns of behavior that are self-enforcing within a group," emphasizing that norms are driven by shared expectations.(no content)A social rule changes over time within the same society—what was acceptable in the past may no longer be the case, and what is acceptable in one society may not be so in another.

## Examples

For instance, it is conventional in many societies that strangers being introduced shake hands.(no content)It is a social norm to provide tips in the US to waitresses and waiters.

Links: [{"title":"Coordination game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordination_game"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Focal point (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_point_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Best response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_response"},{"title":"Asynchrony (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchrony_(game_theory)"},{"title":"It's a Crime (play-by-mail game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/It's_a_Crime_(play-by-mail_game)"},{"title":"2026 Asian Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_Asian_Games"},{"title":"Massively multiplayer online first-person shooter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massively_multiplayer_online_first-person_shooter"},{"title":"Mecha Break - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecha_Break"},{"title":"2021 Islamic Solidarity Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Islamic_Solidarity_Games"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about coordination games:

## Definition

A coordination game is a type of simultaneous game found in game theory that describes the situation where a player will earn a higher payoff when they select the same course of action as another player.

## Key Characteristics

The game is not one of pure conflict, which results in multiple pure strategy Nash equilibria in which players choose matching strategies.(no content)A player's optimal move depends on what they expect the other player to do, and they both do better if they coordinate than if they played an off-equilibrium combination of strategies.

## Real-World Example

A typical case for a coordination game is choosing the sides of the road upon which to drive, a social standard which can save lives if it is widely adhered to. In this scenario, if both execute the same swerving maneuver they will manage to pass each other, but if they choose differing maneuvers they will collide.

## Types of Coordination Games

**Pure Coordination Games**: In this example, it doesn't matter which side both players pick, as long as they both pick the same. Both solutions are Pareto efficient. This game is called a pure coordination game.

**Battle of the Sexes**: In this game both players prefer engaging in the same activity over going alone, but their preferences differ over which activity they should engage in.

Links: [{"title":"Cognitive bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias"},{"title":"List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases"},{"title":"Cognitive bias mitigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias_mitigation"},{"title":"Category:Cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cognitive_biases"},{"title":"Talk:Cognitive bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cognitive_bias"},{"title":"Cognitive bias in animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias_in_animals"},{"title":"Cognitive bias modification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias_modification"},{"title":"Information bias (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_bias_(psychology)"},{"title":"Bias blind spot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_blind_spot"},{"title":"Normalcy bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normalcy_bias"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about cognitive bias:

## Definition

A cognitive bias is a systematic pattern of deviation from norm or rationality in judgment.(no content)Individuals create their own "subjective reality" from their perception of the input, and an individual's construction of reality, not the objective input, may dictate their behavior in the world.

## Effects

Cognitive biases may sometimes lead to perceptual distortion, inaccurate judgment, illogical interpretation, and irrationality. However, biases aren't always negative. While cognitive biases may initially appear to be negative, some are adaptive and may lead to more effective actions in a given context. Furthermore, allowing cognitive biases enables faster decisions which can be desirable when timeliness is more valuable than accuracy.

## How They Work

When making judgments under uncertainty, people rely on mental shortcuts or heuristics, which provide swift estimates about the possibility of uncertain occurrences. For example, the representativeness heuristic is defined as the tendency to judge the frequency or likelihood of an occurrence by the extent of which the event resembles the typical case.

## Origins of Research

The notion of cognitive biases was introduced by Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman in 1972 and grew out of their experience of people's innumeracy, or inability to reason intuitively with the greater orders of magnitude.

## Practical Applications

The study of cognitive biases has practical implications for areas including clinical judgment, entrepreneurship, finance, and management.

Web search results for query: "artificial intelligence agent"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Percept (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percept_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"}]

I found comprehensive information about artificial intelligence agents. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Types and Characteristics

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

## Practical Examples

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request.(no content)Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA, with further examples of agents released since 2025 including OpenAI Operator, ChatGPT Deep Research, Manus, Quark (based on Qwen), AutoGLM Rumination, and Coze (by ByteDance).

## How They Work

Intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals.(no content)A percept is the input that an intelligent agent is perceiving at any given moment. A percept is detected by a sensor, often a camera, processed accordingly, and acted upon by an actuator.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Emergent social conventions and collective bias in LLM populations". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper presents novel experimental results demonstrating the spontaneous emergence of social conventions in LLM populations, plus introduces new findings about collective bias emergence and minority-driven social change.

**Extracted Triples (6 entities):**

1. **Convention (norm)** [concept] - Uses
   - Social conventions are central to the paper's investigation of how AI agents establish shared communication norms.

2. **Large language model** [artifact] - Uses
   - LLMs form the foundation of the AI agents studied in demonstrating autonomous social convention emergence.

3. **Cognitive bias** [concept] - Proposes
   - The paper demonstrates how collective biases emerge from unbiased individual agents, introducing novel insights into bias formation.

4. **Natural language processing** [method] - Uses
   - NLP is the underlying mechanism through which LLM agents communicate and coordinate in the study.

5. **Intelligent agent** [artifact] - Uses
   - AI agents are the core subject of the study, investigating their autonomous development of social conventions.

6. **Coordination game** [task] - Uses
   - Coordination games provide the theoretical framework for understanding how agents achieve social convention emergence.

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all proper Wikipedia references and is ready for use.

Sources:
- [Convention (norm)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_(norm))
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Cognitive bias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias)
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
- [Intelligent agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent)
- [Coordination game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordination_game)
